content.description: Climb seams to a tenuous traverse right.

This climb is very good! The first part is 11d, the second part adds a difficult crux and is quite sustained, at 12d.

The crux is particularly hard to onsight as you can't see where to go... It helps to make a battle plan from the last rest.
content.location: This route starts on the farthest left bolt line on the wall. Spaceballs splits off left towards the arete while Wind in the Willows continues straight up the face.

content.description: A fantastic route that climbs FAR better than it looks and begins in the obvious chimney/groove weakness.  Climb up through steep sections along a variety of bolt-protected crack climbing.  A variety of stems, jams, and face climbing with ample rests will bring you to the anchor 35 meters later.  This route is a FULL 35 meters, so make sure you tie knots in the ends.  Great warmup.
content.protection: 16 bolts, mussy hook anchors at the top, 70 meter rope needed (TIE KNOTS IN THE ENDS)
content.location: The obvious chimney/weakness on the Gecko Wall

content.description: this route shares the start of wind in the willows, then angles left and up to the arete.  climb the arete (shared with eclipse) on the steep side past lots of bolts, sidepulls, and some fun cruxes.
content.location: the far left route on the gecko wall, shares the start with wind in the willows and the anchor for eclipse and wind in the willows extension.

content.description: Start at the bolt line to the right of dark matter, the same line as rage.  At the third bolt, veer into the large recess and head up through the roof.  Follow the obvious line of bolts as the crack goes in and out and slants to the right.  Use a 70m on this one.
content.location: Shares the first 3 bolts of Rage.

content.description:
This is a good route with fun, dynamic movement through the lower portion followed by technical, demanding climbing right before the chains.

It is marred by some chipped/glued holds through the crux, and that's why I assigned this route 2 stars instead of the 3 it would deserve otherwise. I can see why this was done, as without them the route would have a vHard boulder problem above 5.11+ climbing.
content.protection: 8ish bolts? So much easier to clip them when they are hanging already
content.location: Immediately left of atomic gecko. Starts up left-leaning features, before busting right below the big hole/ledge.

content.description:
Tackle a boulder problem directly off the ground leading to a stance on a ledge.  From the stance, launch into thin and insecure face climbing. A hard sequence guards the shuts.

Historical Note:  Originally, the route began on  "Wind in the Willows" and immediately traversed a slopey ledge system over the creek to a high first bolt (somewhat sketchy).  Patrick O'donnell added the direct start in 2015 which makes the route much nicer.
content.location: The second route from the left.  Climbs over the creek.

content.description: Start on Planetarium 12a. Climb to the original cold shut anchor. Keep going and clip a bolt just above the anchor. instead of going left into Planet X 13b, continue up and right following the crack system. Clip 5 more bolts to an anchor at 35m. sustained 5.11 climbing but combined with the first pitch of planetarium 12a it probably feels more like 12b overall. super fun climbing.
content.location: Planetarium (Right) extension.

content.description: Climb Planetarium (12a) via the new direct start. After the open shut anchor continue up clipping bolts and do a desperate boulder problem crux followed by a rest. Then 2 more bolts of endurance 5.12 to an anchor at ~30m. Great rock quality and just right of the Wind in the Willows extension. Just a bit harder though.
content.location: Gecko Wall

content.description: Harder than it looks face climbing leads to a great arête.
content.protection: Bolts. Mussy hooks at the anchor. 60m rope will get you down but it will be close. Tie a knot in the end.
content.location: To the right of the squeeze chimney on the face

content.description: Climb Chronic (or could be done from either Galileo start). Instead of clipping anchor, clip a bolt and continue up above chronic anchor. A fun bouldery move off the anchor leads you left in the the big chimney. Continue up the chimney, stemming, kneebar, and crack climbing. 7 bolts additional above chronic anchor. Anchor at 35m.

Start in a giant chimney Right of Copernicus (13c) and Left of Galileo (13a), which is the direct start. Climb up the Big Chimney (5.9) which merges into Galileo and shares the same ending up the headwall (11c) to an anchor at 35m.
content.location: Right of Copernicus (13c) Left of Galileo (13a).

content.description: Start on a Right Trending Layback Crack-Seam just Left of Chronic (12a). Desperate but excellent liebacking for ~60 feet (13a) to a huge rest. Then finish the climb on the headwall above to 35m (11c).
content.location: Left of Chronic. Right of Copernicus (13c) and Right of a giant Chimney.

content.description: Start on Planetarium. At bolt 8, instead of cutting right to the original anchor, continue up the steep seam (4 new bolts). After some desperate moves with little rest, the route joins with the original Wind in the Willows 1st anchor (13a). Clip the Wind in the Willows extension 1st draw and shake out. Finish on the Wind in the Willows extension. The combined climbing of the 1st anchor (13a) and wind in the willows extension (12d) make this route feel like a solid 13b pitch. The climbing, excellent rock quality, and the fact that it links together 2 of the best routes on the wall will inevitably make this a mega classic hard line on the wall. Enjoy!
content.location: Start on Planetarium.

content.description: The route starts off a boulder just right of the crack in the middle of the wall "Sub Atomic" 10d and just left of "Rage" 12c which is also the shared start for "Salamander Slayer" 11d. A bouldery start leads to basically a no-hands where you head up and left into a clean blank headwall. Several hard cruxes lead to one final difficult heart break crux before the anchor. Probably the red point crux.
content.location: Gecko Wall - Pink Creek

content.description: Start in the big chimney right of Biohazard. Easy stems lead to a bouldery sequence over the bulge. Get a good rest and prepare for hard face climbing to an easier but somewhat sporty finish.
content.location: Right of biohazard.

content.description:
A right-leaning crack with relatively easy entry climbing to a higher first bolt than its harder partner to the left, Galileo. Some grainy jamming could be useful, so plan your kit accordingly. A worthy route with unique style overshadowed by others at the cliff.

Folks have noted a "sketchy flake" on this around bolt four, but it seemed solid enough to me. A helmet is never a bad idea, but this route was put up in 1994 and the holds have definitely been tested by now.
content.location: Between Galileo and Bubonic; the second bolt line to the right of the obvious right-leaning chimney on the right side of the crag.

content.description: Climb the first 5 bolts of Rage. Move right to a lone bolt and the last bolt of Atomic Gecko.
Enjoyable face climbing.
content.location: Just right of the big chimney.

content.description: 25m up canyon from Atomic Gecko and just before the canyon opens up to the Big Horn wall there is a thin desperate crack on the left. Bolts protect bouldery moves through the bottom. a desperate dihedral leads to a stance and final roof crack. bring several pieces for the roof crack. one bolt protects the final crack moves.
content.protection: bolts and a few pieces of gear.
content.location: 25m up canyon from Atomic Gecko.

content.description:
This route is immediately left of the big left-facing corner.

A burly lieback up the edge of the crack/groove leads to a crux move off an undercling. Then some more strenuous climbing along the arching crack. The grade assumes that the wall to the right is off. If you stem, the route is probably somewhere in the 5.11 range.

You can also toprope this route by soloing the easy 5th class chimney in the corner.

This route is between Atomic Gecko and a small recess to the right. The climb is gently overhanging from beginning to end. Climb on good holds past the first few bolts, then make a big reach right (a big wingspan helps). Transfer over into this other crack and make some strenuous liebacking past another bolt before getting a rest. A short section of easier climbing leads to the anchor.

This climb would get more stars if it were longer.

A quality linkup of a bunch of good rock and nice movement. Start on Atomic Gecko. After the 4th bolt traverse right, into and through the crux section of Biohazard. From the anchor of Biohazard make big moves up and right to join Copernicus at the bucket shelf. Shake out and finish up Copernicus.
content.location: Start on Atomic Gecko, finish on Copernicus.

content.description: Climb most of Atomic Gecko then traverse left into the business of Rage. Good Enduro climbing marred by the chipped pockets on Rage.
content.location: Start on Atomic Gecko.

content.description:
This is a classic for the area and it is ON you from the start.  The climbing is pretty thuggy, but there is just enough technical climbing to keep you focussing on your footwork as well.  You will not be disappointed when you rope up for this one.

Venture left at bolt 5 to the neighboring anchors to climb the variation known as Atomic Rage (12d).
content.location: This is the 4th route from the left edge of the wall.

content.description: Start on Biohazard 12a. At the 4th bolt continue up the crack to 35m.

A direct start to Copernicus.  Starting on an obvious triangle jug on the arete (jump start or lean in from some boulders), climb four bolts of powerful, core-intensive moves up pinches and underclings on the steep arete left of the chimney which is the original start to Copernicus.  Merge with Copernicus at a good but strenuous stem rest at the fifth bolt.  It's around 5.13- to the stem rest/fifth bolt and a fun and worthy climb in its own right, though likely harder for shorter folks.  Traversing rightwards out of the bolt line and deeper into the chimney at the fifth bolt is off route.

The climbing on the direct start is fairly unique for Pine Creek - steep and bouldery, on bigger holds, with lots of pinching on the arete and using holds on both sides of it.  al-Shatir climbs the entirety of the 5.13 section of Copernicus, and adds in additional 5.13 climbing, but is broken up by a fairly good if leg-intensive rest.  While definitely harder than doing the original chimney start, for now I am leaving the grade as 5.13+ until consensus is reached.  Regardless of grade, this is a very fun way to start a great route.

Ibn al-Shatir was a 14th century astronomer from Damascus, in present-day Syria, whose work influenced that of Copernicus.  More background can be found here:

adsabs.harvard.edu/full/200…

and

http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu//full/2007HisSc..45...65R/0000065.000.html.
content.protection: 13 bolts to a lower-off. 70m rope needed.  Helpful to have the 9th bolt pre-hung with an extended draw or sling. The first bolt can be pre-clipped by leaning over from the chimney.  Belayer should be extra attentive between bolts 4 and 5 as a fall here can bring the climber close to the right-leaning ramp in the chimney.
content.location: Left of the obvious chimney on the right side of the Gecko Wall.  Just right of Biohazard (left hand uses holds on Biohazard for a move or two at the very beginning).
